courses.name: Biomedical Research at the Cutting Edge

cmCourseInfo.description: Explore the thought processes, logic, motivation, techniques, analysis and impact of recent high-profile publications to gain insight into the enterprise of science. Outstanding scientists present recent high-impact papers, and students will examine the research in depth, focusing on the underlying questions, experimental approach, results and significance.
cmCourseInfo.title: Biomedical Research at the Cutting Edge
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SBI4U and SCH4U (Grade 12 University Preparation Biology and Chemistry); permission of Department

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course has restricted enrolment for newly admitted first-year science degree students with fewer than 4 credits.

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey course intended for students who are not proceeding further in Physiology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Basic Human Physiology
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Any 300-level PSL course taken previously or concurrently

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

courses.name: Introduction to Physiologic Adaptations of Marine Mammals

cmCourseInfo.description: Systems approach to physiology of marine mammals in their aquatic environment. Highlights unique features of cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, urinary, and reproductive systems. Introduces relevant physiology, and makes comparisons to human condition and disease.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Physiologic Adaptations of Marine Mammals

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop

cmCourseInfo.description: Principles of neurophysiology, endocrinology and reproductive physiology for students enroled in Life Science programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Physiology I
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: BIO130H1/BIO150Y1; CHM138H1/CHM151Y1; and 1 FCE from any of the following: MAT135H1, MAT136H1, MAT135Y1, MAT137Y1, MAT157Y1, PHY131H1, PHY132H, PHY151H1, PHY152H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Principles of respiratory, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, and renal physiology for students enroled in Life Science programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Physiology II
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: BIO130H1/BIO150Y1; CHM138H1/CHM151Y1; and 1 FCE from any of the following: MAT135H1, MAT136H1, MAT135Y1, MAT137Y1, MAT157Y1, PHY131H1, PHY132H, PHY151H1, PHY152H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
AEESCBASEB BASc in Eng Sci (Biomedical) students can enroll at the same time as Arts & Science students.

courses.name: Topics in Cellular, Molecular and Organismic Physiology I

cmCourseInfo.description: Control systems, feedback, networks, and both neonatal and adult cardiovascular and respiratory control are the topics examined in detail using homeostasis as a unifying theme. Tutorials involve computer simulations, case studies and/or experimental design. This course is designed for students in the Physiology Specialist and Biological Physics Specialist Programs, although permission is granted to students in other programs upon approval by the Department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Cellular, Molecular and Organismic Physiology I

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course may be added using ROSI/ACORN, but will appear with an interim status until reviewed. It is the responsibility of the student to check whether their status has been approved or refused. For questions, please contact Eva Eng at eva.eng@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Topics in Cellular, Molecular and Organismic Physiology II

cmCourseInfo.description: Molecular, cellular and organismic physiology of the central nervous system, gut, pancreas and glucose-sensing tissues; CNS diseases, obesity and diabetes are used as model systems. Tutorials involve computer simulations.  This course is designed for students in the Physiology Specialist and Biological Physics Specialist Programs, although permission is granted to students in other programs upon approval by the Department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Cellular, Molecular and Organismic Physiology II

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course may be added using ROSI/ACORN, but will appear with an interim status until reviewed. It is the responsibility of the student to check whether their status has been approved or refused. For questions, please contact Eva Eng at eva.eng@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Extend molecular biology concepts to current scientific literature in mammalian physiology. Apply these principles to disease and complex behaviours. Discuss bioethical issues raised by these techniques and their application. Benefit from three weeks in small group seminars lead by research professors focusing on current advances in mammalian molecular biology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mammalian Molecular Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: A laboratory course covering selected topics in physiology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mammalian Physiology Laboratory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO230H1/BIO240H1, BIO241H1)/BIO255H1, BCH210H1/BCH242Y1, MAT100-series/PHY100-series, PSL300H1, PSL301H

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course may be added using ROSI/ACORN, but will appear with an interim status until reviewed. It is the responsibility of the student to check whether their status has been approved or refused. For questions, please contact Eva Eng at eva.eng@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: A problem-based laboratory course focused on the integration and control of organ systems to understand body functions.  Enrollment in this course is restricted to students in the Physiology Specialist and Major Programs although permission is granted to students in other programs upon approval by the Department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Physiology Laboratory

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Regenerative medicine promises to restore body function that has been lost due to disease, damage or age. Students will explore selected molecular, stem cell and tissue engineering developments to better understand how the body normally functions and how cells, tissues, and organs can be repaired or replaced.
cmCourseInfo.title: Regenerative Medicine

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course may be added using ROSI/ACORN, but will appear with an interim status until reviewed. It is the responsibility of the student to check whether their status has been approved or refused. For questions, please contact Eva Eng at eva.eng@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an in-depth review of the development and function of the male and female reproductive systems. Topics include sex determination and differentiation, steroidogenesis, gametogenesis, hormonal control of the reproductive axis, the female ovulatory cycle, fertilization and implantation, infertility and assisted reproduction approaches.
cmCourseInfo.title: Reproduction I: Development and Function

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course may be added using ROSI/ACORN, but will appear with an interim status until reviewed. It is the responsibility of the student to check whether their status has been approved or refused. For questions, please contact Eva Eng at eva.eng@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: General overview of the integrated physiologic events associated with pregnancy and birth. The approach emphasizes physiologic processes using insights gained from studies of humans, animals, cells and genes. Where appropriate the clinical consequences of aberrant development are reviewed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Reproduction II: Pregnancy and Birth

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

courses.name: Integrative Metabolism and its Endocrine Regulation

cmCourseInfo.description: This course integrates the newest findings and experimental approaches from cellular and molecular biology into metabolic function at the tissue, organ and whole body level.
cmCourseInfo.title: Integrative Metabolism and its Endocrine Regulation

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Theoretical treatment of neurophysiology. Mathematical modeling and analysis of neurophysiological systems.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theoretical Physiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course may be added using ROSI/ACORN, but will appear with an interim status until reviewed. It is the responsibility of the student to check whether their status has been approved or refused. For questions, please contact Eva Eng at eva.eng@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to systems neuroscience. A review of basic neuroanatomy and physiology followed by in-depth study of selected sensory and motor systems, with an emphasis on clincial applications in the second term. Students with an elementary neuroscience background progress to reading neuroscience literature on their own.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neuroscience I: Systems and Behaviour

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Overview of the fundamentals of cellular and molecular aspects of brain function. Course material is updated yearly to reflect the rapid evolution of ideas in Neuroscience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neuroscience II: Cellular and Molecular
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSL300H1, PSL301H1, CSB332H1 or permission of instructor

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note

courses.name: Mechanisms of Neural and Endocrinal Secretion

cmCourseInfo.description: Exocytosis and other aspects of secretion mainly in neurons and neuroendocrine cells, but also in pancreatic cells. Topics include synapse anatomy and physiology, synaptic plasma membrane and vesicle proteins, membrane fusion, genetic tools, endocrine secretion, plasticity in neurotransmitter release, diseases arising from secretion defects.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mechanisms of Neural and Endocrinal Secretion

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Biophysics and molecular biology of ion channels. Topics include equivalent circuits for cells, molecular structure of voltage-gated channels, distribution of channels, relationship between single-channel and whole-cell recording, and regulation of channel function by voltage, phosphorylation, G-proteins and metabolites.
cmCourseInfo.title: Membrane Physiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course may be added using ROSI/ACORN, but will appear with an interim status until reviewed. It is the responsibility of the student to check whether their status has been approved or refused. For questions, please contact Eva Eng at eva.eng@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Heart anatomy and development, ion channels and contractile proteins involved in cardiac and smooth muscle contraction are studied. Emphasis is on regulation of electrical and contractile function of kinases, metabolism, volume and ions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Molecular Aspects of Cardiovascular Function

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Development of the cardiovascular system from conception to adulthood with particular emphasis on maturational changes, age-related differences and developmental problems from cellular/molecular to whole organ/system.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cardiovascular Physiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers the physiology underlying sleep and circadian rhythms, and their impact on important physiological processes and health.  The integrative nature of the basic physiological processes is emphasized via discussions and clinical presentations.  Overall, the aim is to present the full spectrum of integrative physiology from molecules and cells to understanding the sick patient.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sleep Physiology and Chronobiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course may be added using ROSI/ACORN, but will appear with an interim status until reviewed. It is the responsibility of the student to check whether their status has been approved or refused. For questions, please contact Eva Eng at eva.eng@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course compares and contrasts the physiological and anatomical adaptations exhibited by the different species of marine mammals in relationship to humans, with respect to diving.
cmCourseInfo.title: Diving Physiology of Marine Mammals

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Research, critique and write a manuscript on a topic of your choice in the scientific literature while guided by classes and assignments that develop advanced science communication skills; and by a mentor expert in your area of clinical or basic physiology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Communicate Biomedical Science
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSL300H1; PSL301H1; PSL372H1; 13.5 additional credits; and permission of Department
